fields.standfirst: Several attempts have been made to regulate the industry
fields.body:
● 1999 Cruickshank report on competition in UK banking

Concluded banks making "super-normal profits" of £3bn–£5bn a year and that banking for businesses was uncompetitive; that the mechanism moving money around the system should be regulated, and that the Financial Services Authority should be required to promote competition.

● 2002 Competition Commission inquiry into banking for small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) banking

Sparked by Cruickshank and forced banks to pay interest on business accounts.

● 2005 CC inquiry into personal current accounts in Northern Ireland

Told banks to give customers 14-days' notice of account changes.

● 2008 Office of Fair Trading market study of personal current accounts

Banks made £152 on each current account but a full-blown referral to the Competition Commission was ruled out.

● 2010 OFT review of barriers to entry in retail banking

A factfinding mission that concluded "the financial crisis has had a major impact on retail banking in the UK".

"One very visible effect has been the consolidation of a number of well-known banking brands resulting in greater concentration across the sector", although "the degree of concentration differs in each product market".

● 2011 Independent Commission on Banking (ICB) chaired by Sir John Vickers

Called for a switching service of current accounts to be set up and a competition investigation in 2015.

● 2013 OFT review of personal current accounts

Banks make £139 for every active current account, the OFT said, but said it would wait until 2015 before conducting another review.

● 2013 OFT at request of chancellor looked at proposed branch selloffs by Lloyds Banking Group and Royal Bank of Scotland

Lloyds was ordered to bolster the profitability of the TSB branches but RBS was not required to make changes.

● 2013 FSA/Bank of England review of regulatory barriers to entry

New banks require less capital to be set up.

● 2013 parliamentary commission on banking standards chaired by MP Andrew Tyrie

Forced the government to look at whether RBS should be broken up; a new non-core division was eventually set up and full break-up avoided.

webTitle: An entire school uniform for just £4. How is it done?

fields.bodyText: It's an offer that sounds too good to be true – an entire school uniform for just £4. For less than the cost of a week's school dinners you can put two polo shirts, a sweater and a pair of trousers or skirt in your shopping trolley along with your groceries at German discounter Aldi. Back-to-school is always a key battleground for the major retailers as the school holidays get under way but Aldi's aggressive entry into the schoolwear market has prompted the kind of price shock not seen since the heady days of the £2 Asda chicken back in 2007. The big question is how is it possible to make, let alone ship halfway across the world and then sell a uniform for such a low price? "It's a crazy price," says Douglas Miller, emeritus professor of worker rights in fashion at University of Northumbria. "You really do have to ask questions about the conditions and the sourcing of this stuff. You are talking about mass, mass production." For Asda the £2 chicken was a loss leader designed to lure customers into the store where it hoped they would buy more profitable products at the same time and it is possible that Aldi is using the same tactic or accepting a much smaller profit margin that is usual for clothing retailers. After spiking in 2010 on the back of floods in Pakistan and other crop problems, the price of cotton has fallen substantially as higher global stocks and weaker demand from China pulls down prices. The sweatshirt the Guardian was sent by Aldi, which is for a child aged 4-5, weighed 160g and according to industry experts would require 300g of cotton fibre to make as losses occur during manufacturing. On Friday the Cotton A Index Price – an internationally recognised benchmark for a daily cotton price – showed 83.05 cents per lb of cotton fibre which works out at 54.8 cents(32.25p) for 300g. But on top of the raw material a retailer has to factor in many other costs such as knitting and dyeing the fabric, labour costs and transporting the finished goods. With the help of a cotton specialist and former fashion buyer the Guardian attempted to break down the cost of a producing a 100% cotton sweatshirt in Bangladesh for £1.25. Most of the production costs – just over 70p – relate to the fabric as the raw cotton has to be knitted and finished, with around 7p to cutting, sewing and trimming, including labour costs. The factory profit is likely to be 11.5p of the finished selling price, with shipping costs of 5p. That would leave Aldi with about 30p to cover the costs of getting the items from the ports to its warehouses, on to its shelves and through the tills. This is a far lower amount than other retailers would accept. Selling prices on fashion are usually at least four times the cost arriving at the port, although grocery retailers are used to working on far smaller margins. Giles Hurley, Aldi's managing director of corporate buying, said: "Aldi works effectively and efficiently to responsibly make operational savings. Rather than using these savings to boost margins, we use them to reduce prices for our shoppers." Sophie Koers of the Fair Wear Foundation, which campaigns to improve labour conditions in the garment industry, said rock-bottom selling prices did not always mean workers suffered more. "It doesn't mean the workers are paid any less. It could be that the retailer is taking the hit on this one. There's this sense that cheap clothes are worse for workers than making expensive clothes but that is not always true. "As we see when something goes wrong, like in the Rana Plaza collapse, you see it's cheap and expensive brands coming out of the same factory and workers are not getting paid more for one product than the other." But Emma Harbour of the Clean Clothes Campaign says that at best textile workers in Bangladesh receive 2% of a completed item's cost. "If Aldi are selling a school uniform pack for £4 then it is fair to assume that the workers producing them are earning at most around 8p for the whole pack," she says. Aldi is ratcheting up the pressure on its rivals amid a fierce supermarket price war. Both Aldi and German peer Lidl are growing at a breakneck pace in the UK as shoppers defect from the big four supermarkets in search of cheaper prices. Aldi's eye-catching offer is a round neck sweater for £1.25, a two pack of polo shirts for £1.25 and a pair of trousers or skirt for £1.50. At £4 the uniform pack is at least 40% cheaper than its major supermarket rivals. Its competitors are privately suggesting that the uniform may not survive numerous high temperature family washes or the rough and tumble of the playground. Nonetheless, a low-cost school uniform will be welcomed by many parents daunted by the expense of a new school year. Aldi says its schoolwear suppliers have to comply with its social monitoring programme, which requires audit reports from final production sites to ensure they meet our standards. "We promote workplace practices and conditions that are safe, fair and legal for all those involved in making our products," said the company. Its suppliers also have to comply with applicable national laws, industry minimum standards and the International Labour Organisation and United Nations Conventions, it said. Its parent, Aldi South, was one of the first companies to sign up the accord on fire and building safety in Bangladesh introduced following the Rana Plaza tragedy. Bangladeshi factory workers may well be receiving the legal minimum wage for their work but at just 5,300 taka it is about a fifth of the 25,687 taka that campaign group Asia Floor Wage argues is the real living wage for the country which is one of the lowest cost textile producers in the world. Miller says there as many as 5,000 factories in Bangladesh but only 1,200-1,500 are "first tier". "It [£4] is not doable unless at the bottom of the rung in Bangladesh where there is very little worker rights. Aldi's Hurley, however, insisted the grocer was able to deliver the cheapest prices by forming partnerships with suppliers: "It enables us to offer shoppers some of the best value in the UK, while supporting fair and ethical ways of working." webTitle: Breaking up banks is hard to do, but it may be the best option

fields.standfirst: The Competition and Markets Authority could go after the big beasts, but my money is on further tweaks and tickles
fields.body:
Who would have thought it, eh? After 25 years in which regulators and politicians merrily waved through almost every UK takeover that crossed their desks, today's competition watchdogs have concluded the banking market is not working well.

It turns out that concentration of ownership has not improved competition or standards. Market shares have become entrenched: four banks have 77% of the market for personal accounts and 85% for business accounts. New entrants struggle to make headway. Most customers think most banks are basically the same so annual switching rates are just 3% in personal banking and 4% among small businesses. And, in that small business market, just 13% of firms trust their bank to act in their interests. So says the shiny new Competition and Markets Authority (CMA).

The only big deal ever blocked was Lloyds TSB's cheeky attempt to bag Abbey National in 2001. Yet seven years later, amid the panic of the banking crisis, the Labour government arranged the marriage of Lloyds TSB and on-its-knees HBOS, an even bigger deal. On that occasion the old Competition Commission did object – but was told to keep its nose out.

The subsequent liberation of TSB, on the orders of Brussels, is welcome but hardly a game-changer, according to the CMA. Its cold assessment: "TSB has a relatively small size and it is unclear at this stage what its overall impact on competition will be."

In part, then, the state of the banking industry is the predictable outcome of a quarter of a century of consolidation. The justification for the deals was cost-cutting, with gains supposedly finding their way to customers. Costs were certainly removed – but benefits for customers did not appear in the form of strong investment in, say, slick technology to make banking easier. Instead, we had disgraces such as the gouging of customers with payment protection insurance.

What should be done? If a full competition inquiry follows, the CMA could suggest three broad areas of remedies. There are problems with them all.

The radical route would be a break-up of the big beasts. For example: let Halifax escape from Lloyds, remove NatWest from Royal Bank of Scotland, and make Barclays reincarnate the Woolwich on the high street. But the costs, which would inevitably rebound on customers, might be hellish. On one tally, Lloyds spent £1.3bn separating TSB. Nor would the exercise be quick. It is taking RBS about half a decade to shed just 314 branches under the Williams & Glyn badge.

A second option would be to abolish free in-credit personal banking. The theory here is that current accounts aren't really free because savers pay in the form of lower interest rates and others pay via high overdraft charges and the like. If true costs were forced into the open by making customers pay upfront for personal accounts, perhaps punters would be more inclined to shop around. Price, after all, is what drives behaviour in other markets, as Aldi and Lidl are demonstrating to the other "big four", the supermarkets.

The CMA will look at the idea. It says the free-if-in-credit model "may distort competition". But would a government of any stripe ever declare that everyone should pay £100-plus a year for a bank account? Whatever the economic models say, the policy doesn't sound like a vote-winner.

The third route is more of the same. That is, more regulatory tickling from the wings: lower capital requirements for new entrants; firmer policing of the intra-bank payments system, the source of too many grumbles from small banks; and greater transparency on lending rates in the small business market, aided by enforced sharing of firms' credit histories. The objection here is timidity. Over a decade, those sky-high market shares might be trimmed by only the odd percentage point.

Which way should the CMA jump? After umpteen banking reviews, let's see the big options explored. That Lloyds/HBOS merger still looks a gross error, so let's have a proper analysis of the cost of breaking up; ditto RBS. If the CMA feels that killing "free" banking would help, it should make the argument whatever the political headaches. Yet more tweaks and tickles would be an admission of regulatory impotence – depressingly, that outcome is probably the way to bet.

Shire's shares in the spotlight

Shire has negotiated decent terms to be taken over by AbbVie. A price of £31bn – £52.48 per share – didn't meet the market's initial high hopes but it's a long way above the £21.50 at which Shire traded a year ago. For good measure, AbbVie will have to cough up £930m if it walks away because US politicians quash the tax "inversion" lark.

So it would be unfair to accuse Shire chief executive Flemming Ornskov of selling his shareholders short because he himself stands to collect $9.9m (£5.8m) in cash just to hang around at New AbbVie for a year. All the same, why does he need a retention payment?

If Shire was being bought wholly for cash, one could understand AbbVie's thinking: Ornskov's long-term share-based incentives would mature instantly and he might walk away. But this is a cash-and-shares deal billed as "a merger". Surely his share-based incentives should just roll into New AbbVie's stock at the merger terms. Then he would have plenty of motivation to stay to make the combo a success.

AbbVie's and Shire's joint statement said "appropriate proposals" would be put to participants in Shire's share schemes "in due course". What does that mean? Will the rollover principle be obeyed or not?

If Ornskov and senior colleagues will be cashed-up in full on their long-term incentives, and then paid handsome retention awards on top, they will be collecting twice. That would be a bad precedent, even if the deal itself is good for Shire shareholders. Before New AbbVie starts its strange life as Chicago-headquartered, Jersey-incorporated, UK-domiciled company, it should clear up this point.

As for the tax "inversion," US politicians should get their skates on if they want to stop the flow of deals. Jacob Lew, US Treasury secretary, this week accused AbbVie of being "economically unpatriotic."

But the company is definitely being economically literate. New AbbVie says it expects to pay an effective tax rate of just 13%. Other US companies will like the look of that.

The Murdochs: Time Warner's new drama

Would Time Warner be the crowning achievement of Rupert Murdoch's deal-making career? Actually, his greatest feat has been maintaining the family's iron control of the empire via voting arrangements that are patently unfair, at least to British eyes.

At 21st Century Fox, the Murdoch family owns about 13% of the company but has almost 40% of the votes thanks to a type of dual share structure that went out of fashion at UK companies about 20 years ago when institutional investors demanded an equal voice for equal risk.

In the US, they still tolerate the idea that a swashbuckling boss, with freedom to act decisively, gets the best results. It's a point of view, but the UK model is best. Why would Warner's investors, who are being offered only non-voting Fox shares plus cash, want to sign up for a long-term punt that Murdoch's children, with mixed business records, can match their 83-year-old father's success? Surely you would want the power to sack them if it all goes wrong.

webTitle: Tesco unlocks its landbank to build 4,000 new homes

fields.bodyText: Tesco is to build 4,000 new homes in an attempt to make use of its vast undeveloped landbank with a £1bn construction programme. The plan, announced weeks after the Guardian revealed that Tesco is hoarding land that could support 15,000 homes, is the biggest housebuilding project ever announced by the supermarket. A Guardian investigation of Land Registry records found that the retailer was sitting on 310 sites that do not currently house a Tesco store. Among the Tesco sites set for housing developments following Friday's announcement will be Welwyn Garden City, Hertfordshire, close to the retailer's operational headquarters, where it plans to build more than 700 homes on a site where it previously planned a store. The trade journal Property Week said the majority of the sites will be in the south-east of England but developments are also scheduled further north, including in Liverpool and the west of England. Schemes include 80 houses and flats on the former Evershed printing works site in St Albans, Hertfordshire. Tesco said it was likely to build homes itself via its development wing, Spenhill, while also selling sites to housing developers, in a programme that has been valued by Property Week at £1bn, based on a valuation of £250,000 per home. A Tesco spokesperson said: "In response to changing customer shopping habits we have decided to reduce the amount of new store space we build each year, building fewer large stores. Where we no longer intend to develop sites, we sell them, lease them or develop them for housing. "We are pleased to be bringing new investment to communities up and down the country and playing our part in meeting local housing needs over the coming years." Last April Tesco boss Philip Clarke cut the value of about 460,000 sq m of its land by £800m as he admitted the company would have to sell off land where it had previously planned to build stores, store extensions and distribution centres. However, the company has been slow to act as the most ready buyers for much of its land stock are likely to have been rivals such as the fast-growing Aldi and Lidl chains. Retail analysts said Tesco was now turning to housing developments because residential development was more economically viable. webTitle: Business founded by Tory donor buys Co-op pharmacies for £620m

fields.bodyText: The family-run business behind the Best-one convenience store brand has bought the Co-operative Group's pharmacy chain for £620m in a deal that will help the struggling mutual pay off its large debts. The deal marks a big expansion for London-based Bestway, which was founded by Conservative party donor Sir Anwar Pervez with one store in Earl's Court in 1963. The Pakistani-born entrepreneur now presides over an empire that includes 64 wholesale warehouses and a network of more than 4,000 independently owned convenience stores under the Best-one and Xtra Local brands. It also owns Pakistan's second largest cement manufacturer and second largest private bank, as well as 64 UK wholesale warehouses supplying small local shops. Zameer Choudrey, Bestway's chief executive, said the acquisition of Britain's third largest pharmacy chain would marry the company's expertise in convenience retailing with a steadily growing new market. It wants to double the size of the 770-store pharmacy business over the next 10 years. "The attraction is primarily demographics – with everybody living longer, there will be more need for medicines," he said. "Like convenience retail, the pharmacy sector is very fragmented; 45% are independents, and that leaves a lot of room for us to grow, not just organically but also via acquisition." No job losses are expected as a result of the deal and Choudrey said Bestway would be seeking a new headquarters for the pharmacy business close to the Co-op's headquarters in Manchester. The company has a year to find new premises as part of a support package in which the Co-op brand will stay above the pharmacy doors for 12 months. Bestway, which achieved turnover of £2.5bn and underlying profits of £220m last year, said the acquisition would help build the UK side of its business to bring it in balance with the Pakistani operations, which contribute more than 60% of profits. Now Britain's seventh-largest family-run business, Bestway is co-owned by five families led by Pervez. The family of his nephew, Choudrey, also owns a stake, as do the families of Younus Sheikh, who is managing director of the UK wholesale business, and the Bhatti and Chaudhary families, who are longstanding friends of Pervez's. The deal is a boost for the Co-op, which is restructuring in the wake of a crisis at its banking division which left it with a £1.9bn capital shortfall. The company now has debts of £1.4bn and the majority of the proceeds of the pharmacy sell-off are set to go towards paying that off. The Co-op's interim chief executive, Richard Pennycook, said the deal will enable the Co-op to invest in its remaining retail, funeral and banking businesses. "Bestway is acquiring an excellent pharmacy business characterised by the quality and professionalism of its colleagues and high levels of customer service. "Bestway in return is an ideal owner, being a strong, family-run group with a proven record of putting the needs of customers first." Choudrey said that Bestway's charitable division, which supports educational projects in Britain and Pakistan and is funded by an annual contribution equivalent to 2.5% of the group's profits, had helped persuade the Co-op to choose the company as the winning bidder.

webTitle: FTSE 100 ends week higher despite Ukraine plane crash and Gaza fears

fields.standfirst: Investors shake off geopolitical concerns as merger moves help push market higher
fields.body:
Martin Taylor remarked at a select committee hearing last week that "the tendency of the markets to ignore geopolitical risk is just bizarre."

Taylor, an external member of the Bank of England's Financial Policy Committee, may have a point, given the market's reaction to the Malaysian air crash in Ukraine, tougher sanctions on Russia from the West and increasing violence in Gaza.

After Thursday's falls following the Ukraine news, and an early drop on Friday, leading shares seemed to shrug off their worries as investors headed into the weekend. After sliding as low as 6690, the FTSE 100 finished 11.13 points higher at 6749.45 after a late rally. Over the week the index has added nearly 60 points. Alastair McCaig, market analyst at IG, said:

The weekend ahead could be busy with geopolitical commentary following Thursday's tragedy, and this will conspire to leave uncertainty as the main driver once markets reopen on Monday. However, the usual pre-weekend squaring of positions helped the FTSE to close a more reassuring distance away from 6700. Earnings come thick and fast both sides of the Atlantic in the coming week, and with a majority of S&P 500 reporters so far coming in ahead of estimates, markets will be able to recover some lost ground if the trend continues.

Shire led the day's revival, up 190p at £49.96 after it finally agreed a £32bn takeover from US group AbbVie.

And ITV was close behind, adding 7.4p to 202.5p in the wake of Thursday's news that Virgin Media-owner Liberty Global had bought a 6.4% stake from BSkyB.

Severn Trent ended 40p higher at £19.26 as risk-averse investors sought a haven for their cash.

Reckitt Benckiser rose 30p to £50.35 as Numis began coverage of the Cillit Bang maker with an add recommendation and £56 target price.

But as gold and silver lost some of Thursday's gains, precious metals miner Fresnillo ended 0.5p lower at 901p while Randgold Resources fell 20p to £50.65.

Banking shares put in a mixed performance after the competition watchdog launched an investigation into the sector. Royal Bank of Scotland fell 4.5p to 319.2p but Lloyds Banking Group added 0.25p to 73.42p and Barclays was 1.6p better at 211.8p.

Elsewhere hospital group Spire Healthcare edged up from its 210p offer price in its first day of dealings. The business, owned by private equity group Cinven, ended at 210.5p.

Another debutant was wood to electricity business Aggregated Micro Power. It joined Aim at 100p and closed at 104p.

Finally failed bullet proof glass maker Pentagon Protection became Yolo Leisure and Technology, a cash shell looking for deals in the travel sector. Yolo, run by ex-Thomas Cook executive Simon Robinson and backed by entrepreneur Chris Akers, closed 2.5p lower at 2.75p as trading in the shares was restored.

3.06pm BST

That's it for today, folks. We are wrapping things up and heading out into the sun. Thanks for all your comments, and have a great weekend. We'll be back next week.

2.57pm BST

Returning to the CMA's inquiy into banking, the Treasury Committee will be taking evidence from the new competition watchdog on Monday.

Andrew Tyrie MP, chairman of the Treasury Committee, said:

Millions of consumers and small businesses have been denied genuine choice in banking for years. The Treasury Committee, the Parliamentary Commission on Banking Standards and the Independent Commission on Banking examined this issue in depth. Everyone concluded much the same: customers do not know how much they are being charged, switching is perceived to be difficult, and would-be competitors in the market face high barriers to entry, often regulatory.

Among other things, in 2011 the Treasury Committee concluded that the regulators should have statutory responsibility for improving competition and choice. This has now been achieved. But it was not enough.

Over a year ago, the Parliamentary Commission on Banking Standards recommended that a market study of both the retail and SME banking sectors begin immediately, recognising that a full market investigation may be necessary. So the CMA’s announcement is an encouraging step forward.

Many previous attempts to reshape banking and provide meaningful competition have faltered in the past. This work is the biggest opportunity for years of better meeting the needs of consumers and SMEs.

2.54pm BST

Wall Street opens higher

Wall Street has opened slightly higher. The Dow has gained 0.3% to 17023.79, the Nasdaq has risen 0.6% to 4389.64 and the S&P 500 is 0.4% ahead at 1966.67.

2.28pm BST

Explaining the Shire takeover to analysts on a conference call, AbbVie boss, Rick Gonzalez, says it's not all about tax, although tax is "clearly a benefit". He insists that the Shire deal has compelling financial and strategic attractions beyond tax. But he doesn't seem to have convinced the analysts or his shareholders.

It is the biggest tax inversion deal to date.

Updated at 2.58pm BST

2.16pm BST

Here in London, the FTSE 100 has recovered somewhat and is now down 0.2%, or 10.6 points, at 6727.83 points (it fell 0.6% earlier). Housebuilders Barratt and Persimmon were among the biggest fallers after brokerage Liberum downgraded its rating on Barratt to "hold" from "buy".

Shire remains the biggest riser, up 2.7% to £49.35, after it agreed to be taken over by US rival AbbVie in a £32bn deal. Here's the full story.

The FTSE 100 Volatility Index climbed 5.4%, reflecting investors' nervousness over the crises in Ukraine and Gaza. Follow the latest developments in Ukraine on a separate live blog here.

Updated at 2.22pm BST

2.10pm BST

The Bank of Italy has cut its growth forecast for this year to 0.2% from 0.7% with "risks to the downside". It is predicting a recovery to 1.3% growth next year.

12.59pm BST

Oil has pushed above $108 a barrel as tensions rose in Gaza, where Israeli troops are advancing, and Ukraine, following the airline crash. Brent climbed 29 cents to $108.18 a barrel while New York crude was up 17 cents at $103.36 a barrel.

11.57am BST

The AbbVie-Shire deal in a nutshell:

11.48am BST

Time for a look at the markets. The Russian rouble-denominated Micex dropped 1.9% in the first minute of trading, and is now down 1.6%. In London, the FTSE 100 index has lost 0.4%, the Dax in Frankfurt has slid 0.7% and the CAC in Paris is trading 0.25% lower.

The rouble, which hit a six-week low against the dollar yesterday, is down 0.27% at 35.08 today.

Updated at 12.09pm BST

11.37am BST

Earlier today, RBS boss Ross McEwan admitted that the investigation into alleged manipulation of foreign exchange markets could pose a bigger problem for banks than the Libor interest rate rigging scandal. Here are the full comments.

We're still doing a lot of investigation. We're going through just millions and millions of emails, chatrooms, conversations to see what actually went wrong, if anything, in this area.

Unfortunately, I have the feeling that this is a sort of Libor case again. The difference this time is that we haven't sat back and denied it. We've gone into it and are doing the investigation hand in hand with the authorities.

RBS paid $612m last year to settle allegations that it manipulated Libor rates, one of several banks that received big fines. Regulators are now investigating claims that traders manipulated key reference rates in the $5 trillion a day foreign exchange market.

11.28am BST

More detail on what Shire would get if the deal fell apart. As reported earlier, it would pocket a £960m break fee. Alternatively, AbbVie agreed to pay Shire "at least" $500m to reimburse it for its costs should the deal fall apart.

Here's some analyst reaction to the AbbVie-Shire deal:

Mick Cooper, analyst at Edison Investment Research, says:

This is a positive outcome for both sets of shareholders and it is pleasing to see that personal egos have not interfered with the commercial rationale.

Updated at 1.12pm BST

11.13am BST

Shire has just put out a trading statement, trumpeting record quarterly revenues of $1.5bn for the three months to 30 June, its second quarter – a 20% rise. Within that, product sales are up 22%. Operating income is up 32% to $630m. It expects product sales growth in the high teens for the full year and raised its earnings guidance to low-to-mid 30% growth, from mid-to-high 20% growth.

Updated at 1.01pm BST

10.59am BST

Committee wants more information from Cable on foreign takeover bids

Meanwhile, the House of Lords Economic Affairs Committee has written to business secretary Vince Cable asking him for further details on plans to strengthen the public interest test to protect British firms from foreign takeover bids. Cable has also threatened foreign firms that break commitments on jobs and investment once they've taken over British businesses with multimillion-pound penalties.

The move comes after Pfizer's (failed) £69.4bn takeover proposal for AstraZeneca in May triggered widespread fears that the US company would break any pledges made on jobs, given its track record.

Lord Hollick, chairman of the House of Lords Economic Affairs Committee, said:

In our evidence session with Vince Cable he was reluctant to suggest that the existing public interest test could be strengthened in any meaningful way. However, since then he has indicated in the media that the government’s powers to intervene in takeovers could be extended.

We have written to Vince Cable to ask him to clarify his position on this issue and very much hope he is now in a position to explain to the committee what he and the government can do to offer important UK companies appropriate protection from foreign takeovers.

You can read the letter in full here.

Updated at 11.19am BST

10.55am BST

Christine Lagarde, the head of the International Monetary Fund, is speaking in Paris. My colleague Angela Monaghan reports that her theme, at the Robert Schuman Foundation, is “supporting the European recovery in a rapidly changing world”.

The territory is familiar: "There is the danger of a vicious cycle: persistently high unemployment and high debt-to-GDP ratios jeopardize investement and lower future growth," she says.

Lagarde reiterates Mario Draghi’s point that there is “more to do” on structural reforms in various economies, which if achieved could add as much as 3.5% to the currency bloc’s GDP by 2019.

She also reminds us of the key recommendations the IMF has made to eurozone policymakers:
- Monetary policy should remain loose until demand has fully recovered and inflation rises back to the European Central Bank’s target of close to 2%
- Economies with the fiscal room to engage in more public investment should do so
- Balance sheets must be repaired to help improve confidence
- Banks should take advantage of more benign market conditions to raise more capital
- Establish a banking union. A common fiscal backstop is still needed to break the link between banks and sovereigns

As ever, Lagarde tells us of the need for deeper economic integration in the eurozone but admits the answers remain elusive. In particular, she stresses the need to maintain an educated labour force that is mobile across borders - “the euro area cannot afford to let its talent go to waste.”

From this perspective, the fact that youth unemployment is so high - an average of 24% across the region - is nothing short of a catastrophe. Its own survival requires that Europe gets the young back to work ... the needs are here and solutions remain to be found.

She concludes:

I think I have pointed out enough areas where concrete achievements are needed and certainly possible. I have perhaps raised more questions than provided answers, but I know that to find the solutions to these critical challenges, a dialogue such as we have today is a key step on the right path.

Updated at 11.05am BST

10.45am BST

Big jackpot for Shire management

Shire chief executive Flemming Ornskov will stay on to lead the integration on behalf of Shire and oversee the creation of a rare disease unit within the new company, reporting directly to AbbVie boss Rick Gonzalez. He will be based in Switzerland. He stands to get a retention payment of $9.9m (£5.8m), equivalent to 105% of its annual pay package.

30 other senior Shire employees will get combined retention payments of $22.9m if they stay on.

Ornskov, who took the helm at Shire in January 2013, holds 22,000 Shire shares and if all his long-term incentive awards pay out, he could land a windfall of up to £21m. His predecessor, Angus Russell, owns shares worth £21m in the company, while the former finance director, Graham Hetherington, who left in March, could pocket nearly £30m from his shareholdings and long-term awards.

Updated at 10.54am BST

10.38am BST

Shire chair Susan Kilsby and Dominic Blakemore, a non-executive director, are to join the board of the combined company, which will be headquartered in Chicago. The takeover hasn't caused the same controversy as Pfizer's abortive £69bn bid for AstraZeneca, Britain's second-largest drugmaker, in May, because Shire only employs about 500 people in the UK, mostly in sales and marketing. The majority of its research is done in the US.

10.20am BST

Shire is best known for its hyperactivity drugs for children, but nearly all its early research is now focused on rare diseases. AbbVie makes the world's top-selling medicine, Humira, a treatment for rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn's disease.

10.17am BST

Shire is once again the biggest riser on the FTSE 100, following its agreed deal with AbbVie. The shares are up 90p, or 1.9%, to £49.

10.15am BST

The AbbVie-Shire deal is not a huge surprise, as the Shire board decided to back it on Monday. AbbVie will pay £24.44 in cash and 0.8960 shares for each Shire share – the same terms as the ones it set out at the start of the week. This values Shire at £53.19 a share. Shire shareholders will own 25% of the combined company.

The main sticking point appears to have been a break fee for Shire, should the deal fall apart. Its tax structure is controversial, amid growing noises from the US about a clampdown on "tax inversions". The break fee is 3% of the value of the deal, i.e. about £960m.

AbbVie plans to create a combined company incorporated in Jersey, the Channel Islands, which will pay an effective tax of 13%, sharply lower than its current rate of 22%, making the deal one of the biggest driven tax inversion.



Updated at 1.03pm BST

10.07am BST

AbbVie agrees £32bn takeover of Shire

Breaking news: Chicago-based AbbVie agrees £32bn takeover of British pharmaceutical firm Shire.

Updated at 10.24am BST

9.51am BST

Coming up: Christine Lagarde is speaking at the Robert Schuman Foundation in Paris at 10am BST (9am GMT).

Updated at 9.51am BST

9.34am BST

Ferrari asks about the CMA investigation into banking. McEwan replies:

It'll be good to have the inquiry. I welcome it, let's get on with it. It's taking the uncertainty out of the marketplace.

This concludes the phone-in. McEwan will be back on LBC in the New Year.

Updated at 9.52am BST

9.31am BST

and the economy? McEwan says:

It's starting to improve, it's actually quite good.

It's starting to get out of the main London centre and starting to spread out.

9.29am BST

He pays tribute to his predecessor Stephen Hester, saying he did an "amazing job" restructuring the business, at a time of great chaos.

9.28am BST

On to the Scottish independence referendum.

The decision is up to the Scottish, McEwan says.

I have a personal view that I'm not putting on radio. It's up to the Scots and 'I'm not a Scotsman. [He's a Kiwi.]

We are having to do some contingency planning as any good business would do.

Updated at 9.54am BST

9.27am BST

That was a focus on revenue, not the customer.

We are doing a lot of change in our business right now.

He defends the bank's job cuts (are there more to come? The bank already hinted at this at its annual meeting when its chairman, Sir Philip Hampton, warned of further branch closures as the popularity of online and mobile banking grows):

I've got too many staff and I've been quite open and honest about that. We need to go through change.

Updated at 9.48am BST

9.17am BST

McEwan wants to "get back to good banking the way it used to be 20 odd years ago." He keeps saying: "we need a better bank".

Updated at 9.18am BST

9.16am BST

McEwan admits RBS still has a lot of work to do.

There are a number of litigation and conduct issues that we are still grappling with.

They will come out over the next 18 months, he says.

Updated at 9.19am BST

9.13am BST

Asked about bonuses, RBS chief executive Ross McEwan says he supports the idea of an incentive payment where people are providing a good service.

Updated at 9.13am BST

9.11am BST

RBS boss Ross McEwan is taking questions on LBC radio now. You can watch here. This is how LBC introduces the phone-in on its website:

webTitle: Shire bosses to receive windfalls after takeover by AbbVie

fields.bodyText: Shire executives will receive multimillion-pound payouts after the British pharmaceutical company finally agreed to a £32bn ($54.7bn) takeover by the US drugs company AbbVie, following an intense set of negotiations. Shire's insistence on holding out for a big-break fee paid off on Friday, with AbbVie agreeing to hand over 3% of the value of the deal – £960m – if it walks away. Alternatively, AbbVie has agreed to pay Shire at least $500m (£293m) in compensation for costs, losses and expenses related to the deal if AbbVie shareholders vote against it. The US company has agreed to incentivise 31 senior members of Shire's staff to stay on after the deal, in a package totalling £19.2m. A retention payment of £5.8m will be handed to Flemming Ornskov, Shire's chief executive, who will lead the integration on the Shire side and oversee the creation of a new rare-disease business unit within the combined company. Ornskov's retention fee is equivalent to around 150% of his annual salary. The remaining £22.9m will be shared between 30 members of Shire staff considered to be key to the future of the combined company. Those employees will be entitled to a cash payment worth 100 – 200% of annual salary and bonus on 30 June 2015. Ornskov, who took the reins in January 2013, could land an additional windfall of up to £21m if all his long-term incentive schemes pay out. His predecessor, Angus Russell, owns shares worth £21m in the company, while the former finance director, Graham Hetherington, who left in March, could pocket nearly £30m from his shareholdings and long-term awards. Shire was the biggest FTSE 100 riser on Friday afternoon, up 1.6% at £48.85. The combined companies will have a workforce of 30,000 and a market value of $137bn. Both companies insisted there was little overlap between the two. AbbVie makes the world's bestselling drug, Humira, for rheumatoid arthritis, and Shire is best known for its rare diseases expertise and treatments for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Richard Gonzalez, chairman and chief executive of AbbVie, wrote an open letter to staff detailing the takeover. He said: "The proposed transaction would create a well-positioned and focused biopharmaceutical company, giving us the opportunity to expand and augment our product portfolio, advance our pipeline, accelerate our growth, and create long-term value for our shareholders. "The companies have complementary strategies, both focused on creating leadership positions within areas of high unmet medical need. Both businesses have complementary areas of strength, rather than overlap. Shire would add new growth platforms in neuroscience and rare diseases." The deal would allow Chicago-based AbbVie to diversify its product range and lower its tax bill. AbbVie wants to shift its tax base from the US to Britain as part of the deal, a move that would cut its corporation tax rate from 22% to 13% by 2016. The drugs firm is one of a string of US companies looking to redomicile abroad to save billions on tax, most notably Pfizer, whose failed £69bn attempt to buy Britain's AstraZeneca in May was partly motivated by the tax savings it could make. webTitle: Reckitt Benckiser lifted by positive broker comments

fields.standfirst: Company could outline future of pharmaceutical division with forthcoming figures
fields.body:
Reckitt Benckiser has been supported in a downbeat market by a positive broker note pointing to the Cilit Bang group's good track record and prospects.

Starting coverage of the company with an add recommendation and £56 target price, analysts at Numis said:

The record has been exemplary: 14 consecutive years of above-industry average growth and consistently strong free cash flow. The new strategy implemented in February 2012 has justifiably been well-received. Adverse foreign exchange movements will mask continuing underlying progress in 2014, but the effect is predominantly translational and this should remain an excellent stock for medium term funds.
Under the new strategy implemented by the current chief executive in February 2012 (designed to shape another decade of market out-performance), there has been an emphasis on higher margin health and hygiene operations and on boosting emerging market sales. Reckitt Benckiser Pharma [is] a non-core business whose future will be detailed with the first half results on 28 July. A de-merger appears probable. RBP could be worth £4 plus per Reckitt share but there are currently many information gaps (e.g. how much debt is assigned to it?) Further M&A is a possibility - the interest in Merck's OTC assets in April proved that Reckitt retains major ambitions.

Reckitt shares are currently 10p better at £50.15.

webTitle: Severn Trent bubbles higher as investors seek havens after airline crash

fields.standfirst: Growing geopolitical tensions unsettle investors and push global markets lower
fields.body:
With geopolitical tensions escalating - the Malaysia Airlines crash in Ukraine, the west issuing tougher sanctions against Russia, and growing conflict in Gaza - it is no surprise that markets are under pressure.

Nor is it any surprise that investors are seeking havens for their cash. So utility companies are in demand, with Severn Trent climbing 18p at £19.04, United Utilities up 3.5p at 885.5p and BG 4p better at 1191.5p.

Gold and silver - also attractive to those feeling risk averse - moved sharply higher in the wake of the crash but have slipped a little this morning. Still, precious metals miner Fresnillo has added 3p to 904.5p and Randgold Resources has risen 25p to £51.10.

And the global concerns have done little to dampen takeover enthusiasm. Shire has risen 25p to £48.31 awaiting the next move from AbbVie in its quest to buy the Dublin-based pharmaceutical group.

ITV has climbed 0.9p to 196p following Thursday's news that Virgin Media-owner Liberty Global had taken a 6.4% stake, which analysts said could eventually lead to a bid for the broadcaster.

Airline shares, hit hard in the immediate wake of the crash reports, have recovered, with British Airways owner International Airlines Group up 1.3p to 332p.

But overall the FTSE 100 is down 30 points at 6708.32.

Among the fallers, banking shares have come under pressure after the competition watchdog launched an investigation into the sector. Royal Bank of Scotland is down 6.1p to 317.6p and Barclays has slipped 0.05p to 210.15p.

Hospital group Spire Healthcare did not choose the best day to make its market debut. The business, owned by private equity group Cinven, is currently unmoved from its 210p offer price.

webTitle: Banking sector faces wide-ranging review by finance watchdog

fields.bodyText: Britain's big four high street banks could be forced to break up after the competition watchdog signalled its intention to launch a sweeping investigation into the UK's £10bn-a-year banking business. Setting out its proposals for an 18-month inquiry, the new Competition and Markets Authority has gone further than its predecessors, who said they would wait until 2015 before considering such a move. The big four – the two bailed-out banks, Lloyds Banking Group and Royal Bank of Scotland, along with HSBC and Barclays – control 77% of current accounts and 85% of small business accounts. These market shares are little changed despite 10 investigations in the last 15 years. The CMA, created in April to replace other competition watchdogs, will consult until mid-September on its provisional conclusion that both small business and personal current account customers get a poor service from their banks and cannot tell the difference between products provided by the main players. The watchdog will be looking at the impact of free in-credit banking, which could be cross-subsidising the industry, as some banks insist that running current accounts loses them money. The banks generate £8bn a year in revenue from current accounts and £2bn from small business accounts, and there are fears that the investigation will conclude with new charges for accounts. Alex Chisholm, chief executive of the CMA, said: "Competitive personal and SME banking markets are essential to households and businesses throughout the country, and to the success of the UK economy. However, our studies have found that, despite some positive developments, significant competition concerns remain which mean that customers may not be getting consistently good service and value from their banks." Chisholm has been called before the Treasury select committee on Monday to discuss the inquiry. Bank shares slipped back on a stock market more concerned by wider geopolitical concerns. The investigation comes at a time when political scrutiny of the sector is intensifying. The inquiry will run beyond the May 2015 election. Ed Miliband had pledged to launch a competition investigation, and shadow chancellor Ed Balls said: "In the next parliament we need to see at least two new challenger banks and a market-share test to ensure the market stays competitive for the long term." The CMA could adopt structural remedies, such as forcing banks to carve new banks out of their existing networks, or it could recommend behavioural remedies – forcing them to become more transparent with charges or to send text alerts to customers when they go overdrawn. As it is, Lloyds and RBS are already being forced to reshape their branch networks as a result of the state-aid terms imposed by the EU during their bailouts. Lloyds has created a new TSB bank on the high street, which is the process of being floated on the stock market, while RBS must break out 314 branches as a new bank aimed at small business customers. The two state-owned banks have the largest market shares, partly because the banking crisis led to a wave of takeovers with names such as Alliance & Leicester and Bradford & Bingley disappearing from the high street and "challenger bank" HBOS being rescued by Lloyds. Chisholm said structural remedies were costly – creating TSB has cost £1.3bn – but should nevertheless be considered. David Mann, head of money at uSwitch.com, welcomed the proposed inquiry. He said: "This is potentially great news for anyone who has a bank account. The CMA has the clout to fix the broken banking industry once and for all, and lay the foundations for a competitive market that works for, rather than against, customers." Stephen Ibbotson of the Institute of Chartered Accountants England and Wales also welcomed a full investigation: "It is right that the CMA is conducting a full-scale investigation into the business lending sector," he said. "If the economic recovery is to be sustainable, fast-growing firms need access to finance to push them to the next level and enable them to expand further." But he warned: "It is crucial that this inquiry does not over-complicate the market." The coalition has already embarked on a series of attempts to bolster competition, including making it easier for new banks to be set up. And the banks had hoped that a new seven-day switching service for current counts would stall any competition investigation. A Treasury spokesman said the government supported an inquiry, even though it comes as George Osborne prepares to ask the public to buy shares in Lloyds, where the taxpayer still has a 24% stake. It is not clear what impact this might have on the sale of Lloyds, or of RBS, in which the government owns an 80% stake. The industry has been aware of the threat of a competition investigation since the 2011 report by Sir John Vickers, and last month attempted to head off a full-blown investigation by proposing a number of "remedies" to the CMA. The watchdog has rejected these ideas, which include setting up a comparison website, establishing new account opening standards, and making it easier to compare accounts. Chisholm said the two-month consultation would be an opportunity for these proposals to be reconsidered. But few expect the industry to be successful in seeing off a full-blown investigation after the CMA found that customer satisfaction levels for the big four banks are at 60%. Even after a new switching service were launched, only 3% of personal account customers and 4% of small business customers switch every year.
